comment_text: I've kept this side of my life off the internet intentionally for 15 years.  It's been strange being a dual YouTuber/Missile Tester, because obviously this side of my life feels very important and the main driver for many of my life decisions.  I'm more than just a person who makes videos and puts them on YouTube, and I feel like I'm kind of introducing you to the other side of me with this video.  I thought long and hard about putting this online after I was asked if I wanted to film my last mission.  I ultimately decided to post this video to let you know that Multi-Domain Operations are real.... and you're in the cyber domain.  I didn't understand the full extent of what the implications of this were until I dug into it more.  Over the course of the next several videos we're going to explore these cyber issues in a very real way.  I hope you'll explore this with me.

War, war never changes. In the year 1945, my great-great grandfather, serving in the army, wondered when he get to go home to his wife and the son he never see. He got his wish, when the U.S. ended WWII by dropping an atomic cloud on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The world awaited Armageddon, instead, something miraculous happened. We began to use atomic energy as a nearly limitless source of power. People enjoyed luxury once thought in the realm of science fiction. Domestic robots, fusion powered cars, portable computers. Then, in the 21st century, people awoke from the American dream. Years of consumption led to the shortages of every major resource. The entire world unraveled. Peace became a distant memory. It is now the year 2077, and we stand on the brink of total war, and I am afraid, for myself, for my wife, for my infant son, because if my time in the army taught me one thing; is that war, war never changes.

Very well done. I believe we have a vulnerability to division, and it's related to how we select our leaders (voting mechanics is what I'm talking about). We don't really select based on our collective judgement of candidate's merits, we select based on who we don't like, and we select based on fear, divisive rhetoric, and our reactions to the EXTREMELY manipulative, and ever present, emotional zeitgeist. This is the realm that forces of division are leveraging the most. I contend that if we fixed our voting mechanics, our risk exposure to divisive, emotionally manipulative rhetoric would shrink exponentially.

Imagine if instead, we voted for our leaders like we do product reviews on Amazon: each of us scores a product (candidate) and gives them a star rating. Then, we pick the winner who has the most total points (points summed up as each score....i.e. if only 100 people voted 5 stars for you, you get 500 points; but if 1000 people voted 3 stars for you, you get 3000 points. I would add one provision: I would reject all voters ballots where they ONLY scored 1's and 5's on their candidates to disfavor the more partisan-driven BS.)

The four star general you interviewed seems to have a better understanding of Plato and Machiavelli amongst other philosophers and authors. Before videos and pictures there were books and paintings. There were and still are a plethora of books available that help shape every individuals’ realities. It’s amazing that we think this advancement in technology is any different than it was hundreds of years ago even though it is. It isn’t that much different from inventing a language to pass along information more easily and secretively the same way we pass along information through encrypted messages through the internet or even video and/or phone calls. A lot of what the four star general has stated is true and the fact that we can pass along information more easily whether it’s through a satellite phone or through a video on YouTube poses a bigger problem; how do we, the receivers of this new information, process this new information and then express what we know and how we know it. This idea leads into philosophy of science which gets to be more complicated the more you read into it, but the point is that all objective truth is subjective to everyone and all subjective truth is objective to us all. A perfect example would of subjective truth is gravity and a perfect example of objective truth is Newton’s theory of gravity. We have gravity which is objective and we do know there have been more than one theories of gravity making gravity a subjective truth. Newton’s theory is subjective because of Einstein’s theory, yet it is an objective truth because it is still widely used and accepted. Now that I have explained that with some doubts...it’s still safe to say that what we post on social media can be used the same way any other tool can be used. You can use it as it was meant to be used or you can use it the way you choose to use it and the more interesting part is that no matter how you use the information it is an evil that will always be correct no matter the receiver used it. During the Vietnam War, I was a junior officer (Captain) in US Army Special Forces ("Green Berets" in their early years).  I was very well trained, at no small expense to the US Army.   That was 50 years ago, and our understanding of our mission was similar to what Gen Brown was saying - because of my job in Vietnam, usually I was given a specific mission, and the information, tools, troops and time that I needed to do it, then told to go do it and rarely told how to do it, unless it involved very complex coordination.  We usually succeeded because of this freedom to operate.  This was why I enjoyed what I was doing - I (usually) had maximum autonomy with minimum command interference - even as a relatively junior commander, and we operated as a team.  I also had the advantage of having some of the best soldiers in the US Army under my command.  We had access to other forces - US and Allied air, sea and not so much cyber, but certainly electronics, and of course the human domain.  The Space domain came later.  We worked as a multidomain team, but it was only after the Vietnam War, and several mission failures which taught the US defense establishment the need for a more cohesive force structure, linked fully, that our military began to develop as Gen Brown described as the current force structure.   I did not make the Army my career, but the experience helped shape my life in my later profession.  This was a very interesting video - Thanks for doing it!

Unfortunately most of the videos out there are either full of hearsay, conjecture, or are simply lazily filled with stock footage and stats pulled from wikipedia. Land Domain/Cyber Domain: Identified enemy location by friendly UAV recieved via radio communication or cyber communication. Commander on the ground communicates to on-station Close Air Support (CAS) assets for strike.

Air Domain: CAS approves strike for laser guided bomb. UAV shoots laser for CAS. CAS identifies laser 10+ KM out via HUD and drops bomb. Bomb lands on target with surgical accuracy without the enemy even hearing or seeing the plane.

Land/Cyber/Human Domain: US Infantry squad builds Walmart in that same village and all inhabitants are happy, tweeting that America is awesome.

I haven't taken the time it would take to read the thousands of comments that have been posted to this video so this has likely been commented on earlier in the comment stream, but it bears repeating. One cannot consider the idea of "domains" to be new. Military forces, no matter how old they are or what country they fight for, have ALWAYS fought in these domains. A perfect example of that was when one of the speakers referenced a US Civil War conflict on (presumably) the Mississippi River. What is new here is the realization that all branches of a country must be able to operate in all of these domains. Once upon a time, the Navy and the Army would not even speak with one another. The first step to ending the interservive hostility and jealousy was the creation of JSOC. It became mandatory that the Navy, Army and Air Force work together to solve problems that, at that time, one branch could not accomplish by itself. In me opinion, JSOC was a huge step forward. It was not just for use in the war on terror, but virtually ANY conflict that popped up. As with most things, understanding the "problem", whatever it may be, is paramount to dominating your opponent or, optimally, convincing your enemy that he cannot win. The Japanese Samurai had a saying that is on point: "Win now, fight later."

There might even be another domain that appears to be rolled into the human domain and that is the psychological domain. Amazing and almost unbelieveable things can be done to a fighting unit in PsyOps actions. I have to assume that this "domain" has been considered since these people are obviously smart folks and would not have not forgot about it.

The discussions with our soldiers, sailors, etc. in this video were particularly interesting in that they told me that inter-service rivalry has morphed from a fatal flaw into a true strategic and tactical advantage.

I did a report on Cambridge Analytica and Brexit and Trump. I found that through your online activity they can accurately interpret your 'psychological profile' - to do with how you respond to content etc. I try to be as deceptive as possible - liking things I don't like, not liking things I do like... The thing is that this data can be very dangerous especially for people who through that vulnerability can be further manipulated for ulterior motives. Myself I see the internet as a resource like a library, however that brings into questions standards of publishing - it is my opinion that publicly available access should be filtered heavily and users should have to opt into VPNs to have unfettered access to the internet. That is a huge implication when considering internet content. We are all bound by service agreements with our ISPs and that agreement has legal implications that place responsibilities on providers in terms of ensuring 'quality' of their service. When there are websites and applications that harvest user data and in turn use that data to influence and manipulate people you find results where specifically millions of people being targeted with slick advertising designed specifically to pull at your heart strings in order to manipulate your decisions. My conclusion that this was a serious breach of user trust. Computers themselves have an enormous amount of untapped potential and these sorts of techniques I'm discussing are incredibly dubious in terms of what is legally and socially acceptable. Privacy is the central concern here and that matter concerns fundamentally the fact that all software if designed and implemented correctly should be tested against all conditions and scenarios. Hence vulnerabilities are not just poorly designed software components - they are intentionally placed into systems to allow for surveillance. In terms of the potential of computers - when people suggest that systems are impenetrable etc they are lying. When it comes to the potential of computers it is a matter of what tools you have at your disposal, any computer is capable of building tools to run such that there is no information nor software artifact that can not (in theory) be synthesized on a computer. As such it is all well and good to build products designed to spy on people / violating their privacy - I just hope they understand that information is superfluous in the sense that all other information exists in dormant potential states in memory and that is everything! Great video! This is a very obscure, niche subject to the average American that I think is important to understand. Having been a GS employee working on strategy and capability requirements at a 4-star command, I have been immersed in this subject, and I am familiar with the Army's development of Multi-Domain Battle as it's guiding operating concept.  The old binary construct of peacetime and war has recently been replace with what the general alluded to; a constant state of competition of varying intensity across all domains. And at the Dept. of Defense (DOD)/Joint Chiefs/SECDEF level, the term Competition Below Armed Conflict (CBAC) has been adopted to describe exactly kind the threats in the cyber domain such as information warfare that the general described so well. I am biased, but I think that with regard to this subject, the Joint Staff and the services are far ahead of the rest of the U.S. government in recognizing and analyzing the threat and its implications, and trying to develop solutions. But, DOD can only affect how military operations are carried out, and cannot affect the development of a coherent and coordinated U.S. government strategy (what is referred to as a Whole-Of-Government effort). That is what we are lacking, which is why I believe we are currently losing to our adversaries. Since we are not shooting at each other, it's easy to think we are not engaged in a conflict. But make no mistake, we are under attack here in our homeland every day. Not by missiles or bombs, but in the cyber domain and through the use of extremely effective information warfare.

This is why I love to play Civilization V (yes, there are newer ones, but V is my favorite). Many turn based games like chess and Risk are all about military victory, but Civilization incorporates economics, technological research, cultural influence, religious influence, food and resource management, population happiness, and population growth on top of all the military aspects. Unlike chess and Risk, military might can crumble in the face of economic espionage, or political accosting. Go on a war campaign, and you can end up fighting other nations that have treaties with your target, and neutral countries may even place embargoes on your trade to make supporting your war more difficult. On the flip side, you can wage proxy wars by donating money or military resources to the nation you wish to see be victorious. It's so much more than whacking someone over the head with a club, and after really getting into Civ, chess feels lackluster and too limited.

Barking Sands, Kauai is named for the tiny shell fragments in the sand dunes there. What you do is, jump off a sand dune and land feet first into the sand below. The friction of your feet penetrating the sand makes a “bark” sound. Hence, Barking Sands. I worked on Kauai after Hurricane Iniki and used to surf at Majors Bay in Polihale Beach Park. Right there next to Barking Sands Missile Base in this video. If you know the girl surfer that lost her arm to a shark (she was on Amazing Race years later), Majors Bay is where she was surfing when the shark got her. I was there about five years before that and I remember the water feeling “sharky”. Plus I was surfing alone. My girlfriend was taking pictures on the beach. I got out of the water after a few waves and told my girlfriend, I didn’t SEE any sharks but I felt them. So I didn’t go back in the water. Years later I heard about the girl getting attacked there. Spooky. Anyway, in the video you can see Majors Bay. It’s the beach just to the left of where the missile base is launching from.

But there is a trap in the 'political grace' concept and that is this: what are the end posts of the political spectrum that are (1) allowable and (2) acceptable? Without known end posts, one may extend a courtesy to accommodate or listen to an opinion from an entity that is well beyond an acceptable endpoint. For example, a comparison of the ideas emanating from what was considered the 'far right' in the 1960s and 1970s are very much different than the ideas of the 'far right' in the 2000s and 2010s. [Note: I am using the 'far right' due to the fact that I have first-hand knowledge and experience in both time periods and the differences in the ideas of the right are greater, thus easier to document, than the differences of the 'far left' goals for these same two periods.] While the 1960s and 1970s endpoints are worthy of consideration at both ends of the spectrum, those of the 2000s and 2010s are not as they are not representative of the founding principles of our government; they are incompatible with it. This is where the deception comes in - the changes in the end posts of the far right are not reflective of true changes but are the result of propaganda, much of it external in origin, which has been adopted by a minority of vociferous internal entities. Thus the spectrum itself has been skewed and what was not acceptable or allowable in the earlier decades has been given an appearance, though false, of acceptability. (Example: the KKK tried to hold a rally in my hometown in 1970 and the group was told in no uncertain terms that it would not happen - that is in line with this country's principles. Today, I am not so sure the right choice would be made.) To grant these false end posts any validity is to have lost the argument before you knew you were having one. At some point, one has to stop and say "No. That is not acceptable in this country." (To see this in action, watch the US Ambassador to The Netherlands in his first press conference - I think it was early 2018 - and it becomes increasingly evident what 'freedom of the press' means and why, on an international scale, the US has slipped to #48 - just shy of being in the category of authoritarian governments - in the most recent rankings.). Before the extension of political grace, you must be aware of the pitfalls encountered in assuming that all positions, including the false ones, have equal validity and represent the strengths of this country. You do have to draw a line in the proverbial sand and defend it against all enemies.

I feel like the US is more divided than ever. And I wonder if that is, at least in part, the planned result of operations being carried out in the cyber domain. I have had this thought rolling around in my head ever since Russians incited a protest in Texas using nothing but social media.

It is said that during WWII, Japanese admiral Isoroku Yamamoto said that "to invade the United States would prove most difficult because behind every blade of grass is an American with a rifle." There has been much debate regarding the authenticity of that statement, but the implication made it easy to believe. America was strong during WWII. Not only because of its numbers and resources, but because the nation back home was proud, resilient, and unified. If an invasion were to have occurred on American soil, the military would not have been the only threat; the invaders would have had an armed and prideful population to deal with. So how do you weaken such a nation?

Create social discord.

27:06 "I believe the biggest threat right now is division. They're going to find the biggest division within our society, and they're going to try and amplify it."

Immigration, health reform, abortion, and most notably, gun control. All of these are hot button issues, and using the cyber domain to amplify tension between opposing groups is viable method for increasing division and unrest in our society. Take the previously mentioned protest in Texas as an example. It was found that Russian linked Facebook pages were responsible for coercing both sides of the conflict; pinning Muslims against Texans, and resulting in a public protest in Houston. As senator Richard Burr stated, "From a computer in St. Petersburg, Russia, these operators can create and promote events anywhere in the United States in attempt to tear apart our society." Based on these events, it's not too farfetched to believe these types of cyber tactics are being performed on a daily basis for any given topic; a topic such as gun control.

Weakening a nation's unity is one thing, but disarming a nation is another thing altogether. And what's a better way of disarming a nation than making them disarm themselves? I believe any further discussion about this idea would very quickly have me accused of "tinfoil hattery", so I will just leave it at that.
The internet is a very toxic place these days. It's almost impossible to find a single YouTube video or web forum that does not contain severely negative interactions. And the scary part is that, due to anonymity, the internet is a place where people are free to express their true emotions and ideas. These hurtful, and even hateful messages are coming from the core of their being. People are being habituated into the "us vs them" mentality; moving ever further away from the unification that it takes for a society to flourish. And it's not only America. The far reaching fingers of the internet is spreading this virus on a global scale.

Proactive, intentional unity, brought forth by patience and political grace sounds like an effective countermeasure to combat this troubling dynamic. I just hope it's not too late to be deployed.

In the art of war, there are 4 major stances that can be taken. I will do my best to explain them, and their divide.
Your imposing stances (strategies) fall into two categories. Let's call them A and B:
A involves improving your own position.
B involves hindering your opponents position.
In a perfect world, we don't ever resort to B, because that will certainly lead to war.

Now, there are also two possible reasons someone would act against the best interests of the world:
There are Evil reasons for imposing your will.
Then there are Stupid reasons for imposing your will.

These are traits that can be applied to oppositions, or yourself.. Both versions of imposing your will are a mistake, either because it's easier for you, or because it fulfills imposing stance B.
(A good example is Trump. Is he evil, or stupid? Either way, he's acting against American/EVERYONES interests.)


Taking into account these four factors, you're left with a logical system that promotes a unified alliance between all nations.. also world peace.. That means we're playing the earth like an MMO, which happens to be my expertise.. The only correct answer is A, or to improve your own position. Avoid B like the plague, and don't be evil. The way it looks to me is that multi-domain operations have always been a part of warfare.
Maybe not under the SCALS principle, which is a modern interpretation of war on it's own, but it always has been.
What we call land now, back in the day, was siege, cavalry, infantry, heavy infantry, supplies, etc.
Just because high command classifies it as one sector, doesn't mean it isn't a complex machine of dozens of smaller machines with in turn hundreds of parts.
War has always been a complex combination of dozens of different factors, it's only because of information throughput getting to the point where individual real time feedback of grand scenarios is possible, and the technologies that have gone into warfare, that every single different sector, be it land, sea or air, is able to interact with each other on a macro level.


War isn't changing, and neither is the method we fight with.
In warfare, there are only 2 factors that ever change.
Information and weaponry.
And whoever can utilize the most information the most effectively, and has the superior weapons, can win a war.

This is what the Wehrmacht was touching the tip of when they empowered their field commanders during the Blitzkrieg through France. German generals relied on their field commanders to solve their own problems on their own time instead of waiting for the chain of command to give them all their orders. They smashed through the French lines while the French field commanders were waiting for orders to be brought back from the command posts behind their lines. Modern militaries have taken this basic concept and applied it to their entire operation. Every soldier, officer, and commander has the intelligence and training to make decisions on the fly and not have to rely on the people above them.

After the Vietnam War, the military realized that if they wanted to control and manipulate the view the public had in order to prevent democracy from actually influencing them, they had to control the media. I think there is yet another domain, one that knits those five plus the human domain, and one that seems at the present largely lacking, not only as to being developed but even the awareness of the need to do so, and that is the ontological domain.

This domain is in part embraced by concepts such as the semantic web, artificial intelligence, data mining and such. And some tools are emerging such as OWL which is a language to describe ontologies. But these it seems are just fledgling starts.

Now one might think of an ontology as going beyond knowledge and even information and trying to model understanding. Thus when a computer program says creates a triangle it has operations it can perform on triangles but that software falls sort of really understanding just what a triangle is.

And just how one goes about approaching modeling understanding is a tall order. But larger than address the hows to do that it might be worth describing the benefit of being able to do so. For the over all benefit is what systems engineers often call managing complexity. For take a specification to build a system, be it a simple device or something complex like an aircraft or aircraft carrier.

To do that there need be numerous requirements documents to describe what the system must do under what constraints and schuh. Then design documents, test document, training manuals, and the like. But Even with all those the ontology model that links all these together tend to be in the heads of those that write those documents and those who then s=read and carefully study them.

An ontology model could be the glue that links all these together into a coherent whole . In doing this it can serve not just as a really smart search engine but can maneg the flow of information and the allocation of resources such that information can be pushed to users and bandwidths and menory allocated and managed to facilitate that flow of information.

It can also perform diagnostics, authentications, and security to detect intruders or unauthorized operations and the like. It can also help perform configuration management.

Now there are stand alone tools that domany of these nd the ontology model should not try to reinvent those wheels but rather integrate those "stove pipes" so that they can work together.

Finally, an ontology model must be user friendly, easy to use, scalable, extensible, cloud friendly, robust, etc. Ceruan tools like OWL have been developed that seem ot be a good step in the right direction but are not all that user friendly but have a really steep learning curve..

Now just such an ontology model might look like is a good question and this might be a good starting point to developing such an ontology model by devising various approaches of how such a model might indeed look like. and researching to see what others may be doing along those same lines.

BTW, for anyone that might have an interest, my YouTube channel shows number of attempts to do that and show conceptually what an ontology model might look like.

Reading the comments I see a lot of interesting take-away, but also a few points worth addressing:

1) Destin absolutely knew going into this video what it was and what it means to the military. It's clear from the very beginning that this weighs heavily on him. That does not change the fact that the content is interesting and useful to have out there for discussion. This was also a rare and tremendous opportunity to share a deeper view of modern military process, equipment, and tactics, separated (mostly) from the current political discourse, and I think Destin would have been a fool to pass it up. I suspect the General and others in his command structure wanted this message out there specifically to bypass the current discourse and convey a message they see as important. That in itself is... interesting to think about.

2) He was not truly surprised at the video being a "weapon", he led the admiral into a question he had pre-loaded in his mental interview notes. He does this all the time in his videos with people he interviews and even specifically discussed it in regards to his interview with Obama. He uses this tone and tactic to connect with the interviewee and relax them. (He also overthinks everything so it would be silly to even consider he hadn't thought about this for days before hand) This also led the General to be more honest with us, the viewer, which is a positive, because we walk into the rest of his statements with our eyes wide open.

3) The general's message was very patriotic and America-centric, and if you've ever known anyone who's gone through basic training, you know why. Destin's comment at the end, notably, was not. I'm certain that was deliberate and that is very important to acknowledge. The cyber/human domains we are talking about here don't follow national boundaries any more than they follow traditional conventions of warfare. They are ideological weapons as much as they are state weapons, and the need for unity is a multi-cultural, world wide human need to effectively prepare for any attempt to divide and conquer. I applaud Destin for approaching it that way.

I don't imagine he'll read this but I'll say it anyways: Thank you Destin for taking this opportunity to share this information. I know it's controversial and many will disagree with it, but I think there's a lot of value in having this train of thought in the military out there for public awareness, and far beyond the speech on the surface. It's also really cool to see just how wild your job has been for the past 15 years and put that in perspective with what you do for the channel. I'm sure it's been a special challenge to balance. Keep getting smarter and helping others do the same.
Despite everything, that is a job I will want

The biggest lie of the internet is saying that it doesn’t affect real life. “It’s just the internet, don’t need to take it seriously” is a common argument. Bullying from the internet has gone into real life and viceversa. Now charity events have become something common on the internet, real people donating real money for real causes over the internet. Now criminals can pull info from the internet to do their felonies, be it felonies committed fully on the internet with real life consequences or felonies that end up being committed in real life. For good or bad the internet has always had an influence on real life, it’s time people get off that early 2000’s mentality that the internet is only a place for fun.

I know what you mean man. As a former AF ammo troop, who worked mainly in the conventional and line-d sections in a test group, we got to see many things that were brand new into the service.

The entire concept of a fully domination of every domain in warfare is extremely important. Its why the F35 is so important, giving a commander a fully scope of the battlefield with its interconnectivity. Having the ability of the multitude of AEW&C systems all talking, will allow the critical decisions of using a CAS platform, be it fixed wing or rotary, mortar or artillery support would be critical. Even air launched weapons that are getting smaller and more precise to lower collateral damage, but still with the same lethality to neutralize the target. That would atleast cover the air and land domains, and I cannot really comment on sea as I was not working with many systems that involved sea based weaponry.

Then you go into the space and cyber domains, and alteast for space domain, I have absolutely no idea what could happen as it is such a new concept. The only thing I can think of in that area would be the satellite usage. Having imagery, radio, which could be considered both in space and cyber, and I would say some sort of space based weaponry if that is even possible at this moment.

Going into the cyber domain, you can have much, much more propaganda now as the world is so much more interconnected. You can have deception, like you said, to either cause, or calm the general population, as well as the government and military of other nations. Then you can have systems that would trick enemy systems to present them with false data, or rerouting the weapon systems if they have been already deployed. Like Gen. Brown said, the soldier today, unlike days past, has access to much more support from the entire US military, with many options on what they would need. Just by having this video, and showing the amount of effort we are putting into multiple systems, could be a deterrent, but at the same time, it could be a push for other nations to push for their own systems.

I really think that the faster the US can fully integrate all weapon systems, and I mean integrated as in like the "future" generation of the Ghost Recon series of shooters, plus another few steps over top of that. It is kind of sad that I am separated now, and cannot see what kind of advancements we can make now. Its amazing looking back, to know that back then, I really did not see it as an amazement in advancements for the systems that I had my hands on working with the test engineers. Yet now, looking back, there were some serious leaps and bounds in interconnectivity and the ability of the USAF to do damage to others, while reducing the chances of friendly casualties as well as collateral damage.

Overall, I agree with the last line, but the past two-something years have been different. A lot of truly despicable behaviors have come out of the woodwork, from people who are feeling emboldened and safe to say and do these things. Sure, we can discuss whether X fiscal policy or Y fiscal policy is better, but when the debate becomes "do we strip the rights of X group of people?" or "how do we best dismantle the systems that have been put in place to protect our people?", those are very different problems, and equivalencies become false. To make literally everything worse, climate change is already affecting us and is the most serious threat we've ever faced, and far too many of the people in power don't take it seriously.

My point is that a good proportion of the division we're experiencing has to do with issues that have extremely severe consequences for many groups of people, and saying "we need to come together" is good, but when you're talking about, say, racists who want to kill people vs good normal people, the middle ground is still way too far in the bad direction. With climate change, the middle ground is still largely the destruction of our species.

Ultimately, the problem is that our government (I'm speaking from the US perspective, since I don't know enough about others) is no longer owned by The People. This isn't a partisan issue, it's a systemic disease that has infected almost everything. I think we the people would feel a lot less divided if we felt like we actually had a voice. Getting money out of politics is the solution to so, so many of our problems. If that actually happened and our government was run by people who actually represented The People, sure, we'd still have division, but the voices of the worst people would be more drowned out by those of the decent people majority.

Man most of these comments are either edgelords or political activists. xD Can't we just talk about the contents of the video? Here's my attempt to do so anyway.
Multi-Domain Warfare is an evolution of Combined Arms Warfare. Combined Arms was all about umbrella command to increase co-operation between the three primairy domains (Air, Land, Sea). Multi-Domain seems about increasing the practical intergration to improve the same, with the addition of the Space and Cyber domains(the function if which is mostly communication, information management and deception). So rather than simply having unified plans and being ABLE to co-operate, it is more about inherent co-operation between the domains.
As the general said, it's a matter of getting out of the "This is MY wheelhouse" mindset. A more complete integration of all combat elements made possible by the space/cyber elements.
The evolution of war is a fascinating and terrifying beast.

When I saw the title of this video -- "The Future of War and How it Affects YOU" -- I had to watch, even though I knew that it would be inherently limited in how it treats the future. I'm a university-trained futurist (MS, Studies of the Future, University of Houston - Clear Lake) and currently studying toward a PhD in Sociology, so I recognize that there isn't "the future": there are a lot of alternative futures out in time, and we generally need to be more aware of the possibilities if we're to make good choices about the future.

In a way, General Brown touched on this, though in a limited fashion. He acknowledged that there are many different routes to a goal. What he didn't mention (although you hinted at it in a round-about way) was understanding social construction. It's important to understand how you perceive the world: that's shaped in large part by the people around you and how you and they interact. If you only interact with the same people, you never generate new ideas, because you all tend to think alike. But it's even more important to realize how limited your perspective is: different social groups think differently, and being able to see your own blind spots while seeing into theirs gives you a tremendous advantage.

But perhaps more important is the ability to see beyond and behind the obvious futures that many people tell us are inevitable. Those futures are not inevitable: we have the power to change them if we are aware of alternative futures' existence. Singularly, we can't know much about the future: we tend to get sucked in by shiny technologies and how people propose to use them to solve problems. But many of the most interesting futures are about social change, and particularly how changing our perspectives on social issues and structures changes everything else: politics, economics, technologies and how we use them, just to name a few. Together, we can explore each others' blind spots and illuminate the hidden assumptions that prevent us from seeing those alternative futures that we'd rather have -- like effective diplomacy making armed conflict a less inviting solution for resolving competition.

I went into the UHCL Studies of the Future program thinking that science and technology drive society. I came out understanding that society drives science and technology. That's why I'm taking a PhD in Sociology -- to better understand how we choose technologies that become central to the futures we create.

This was an incredible video. To have a General say thank you for being interested in this is mind-blowing. The time I served in the military I was a Cannon Fire Direction Specialist for a platoon of 155mm Howitzers. We had a Reforger exercise in the late '80s where we took everyone in the 8th Infantry Division and simultaneously fired into a grid square on a firing range. There were multiple units of 155mm Howitzers, 203mm Howitzers, MLRS(Multiple Launch Rocket System) and several other units. We planned on doing a Time-On-target. The plan was to have everyone fire at a target at a specific time. Being a 13e in a unit and speaking fluent German gave me plenty of opportunities of seeing things and doing things. At that time I drove our Lieutenant around speaking to Germans about setting our unit in towns and helping with any problems that came up. I was able to go to a forward observation area and witness the rounds coming in. It was the coolest thing to see. Not just seeing what we normally fired at, but to see what that many rounds can actually do to the enemy. On a scale from 1 to Awesome, you definitely get an Awesome for what you did. I must have been so hard not to be able to talk about everything you have been doing. Glad they gave you the ok. Some really cool stuff.

I’m going to throw a few notes in here for those interested, as this is the thing I study. You’ve basically got 4 types of power in the cyber/human domain: compulsory power (I make you do something), institutional power (I make you do something through a medium/vector), structural (I change the rules of the game/nature of the fight that forces you to do something), and productive power (I affect your strategic outlook so that your perceived options fall along lines I want). Cyber cuts across all of these and unlike a column of tanks it usually falls below the threshold of an act of war, and affects the target psychologically so that they are much more divided/confused and ineffective if we do decide to escalate into a conventional conflict. It’s fascinating stuff

A big driving force for cyberwar is the creation of questionable or simply fake news. Videos and photos can be taken out of context and/or can be manipulated in any concievable way, live if nessecary.

What we could do about this is create fool-proof ways to sign and verify digital footage at every step in order to separate reputable sources from fake ones.

Imagine this. President Trump does a live speach. People ready their cameras. The cameras (and any other equipment involved in the recording, processing and transmission) have digital signing hardware aboard that makes sure each second of footage they record cannot be altered without anyone being able to detect it and will always be tracable to the piece of equipment that recorded it. The security stream also contains timestamped digital signatures of people who use the equipment (journalists?) themselves, GPS data the equipment recieves from the GPS system that now also transmits a verifiable signature from the satellite along with coordinate data, and signatures of involved third parties, such as journalism companies.

Now other people (including the president himself and his staff) also can sign each others combination of signatures with their own timestamped signature. It's basically a way of vouching for someone that they have been there with the signed piece of equipment in the same place at the same time.

So, wherever this video is streamed, downloaded or transmitted along with it's digital security stream, you know it's sources, you know it's place of origin and you know when it's unaltered.

Now then:

Hm... I don't really feel like any of this is really new, at least not since... horses, telescopes?

I mean, some things really change things, but the core ideas are the same.
I mean, you go from an army that charges straight forward to one that shifts to the side and ambushes you, or from one that has to march on foot to one that can use horses and suddenly you can move far faster. Go to one that can sail around the country, or others, rather than ride through it and that can be very significant. But the basic idea is the same, out maneuver the enemy and appear where they do not expect you. guns are a step up because you don't have to be in sword range, automatic weapons are an even larger step up because you can throw out more lethal attacks quickly, and mortars, missiles and torpedoes are a step up from that being able to deal area and structural damage from long distances.


You go from climbing trees and hills and looking through a telescope to using a drone or satellite that can let you view things from miles away and that changes things, but the core idea is just getting more information.

You can go from stealing, destroying, or subverting food, communications, ammo, detection etc. via physical means to leaking false information to double agents to hacking radar systems etc. and the core concept is the same as always, limit and deceive your enemies.

You can go from paying merchants pre-war to talk about how many soldiers you have when traveling through an area to dropping pamphlets to twitter and the idea is the same. Speed of transmission and dispersion have changed significantly and that may change it's effectiveness but the concept and goal hasn't. Moralize your soldiers and demoralize theirs.

Even being able to tell a soldier what to do rather than how isn't new, that's what leaders have been telling generals since the dawn of time. The difference isn't in being able to tell someone what to do, it's what you can tell them to do. If a solider can go from having to scout out many paths from one place to another in person with the constant risk of being killed doing it to telling a group of others to do it to using accurate paper maps and information about enemy locations to real time (thermal) imaging in minutes and can activate weapons around the world with a few key presses, that changes what that soldier can reasonably be told to do. But you still don't want every private in the military to be making those decisions rather than trained officers xD

The domains aren't new, the effectiveness and additional capability is but little of what was mentioned in the video, besides cyber, is even new since... WWII?

Direct confirmation of the US Armed Forces re-orienting themselves towards the cyber and human domains is somewhat frightening.. We've all felt the low-key push and pull of international powers in play in our collective backyard of the internet. Of political action and politics in general possibly being scrutinized in the same manner as one would a battlefield. And the dangers of the Armed Forces being implicitly politicized by that action alone.

I guess its also frightening because the traditional domains can be passive deterrents. But that the cyber and human domains are relatively hot. If we were to use traditional terminology, small wars and skirmishes are being fought through the medium of our backyards and our minds. And that division is perhaps not the target, but the aftermath of this fighting.

I'm a Subscriber, and a huge fan of your Channel. I am also a fellow engineer (civil hydraulics, retired), in my 80th year. WRT this topic -- modern warfare -- US/NATO advanced military capability must be maintained because there are bad actors out there -- chief among them, Putin - who want to destabilize and then control other countries or portions of countries. The US responds to this threat through the ongoing massive development of military capability, believing that "if our enemies can see that we are so far advanced in our war-making/winning capability, then we will ensure lasting peace". I would like to politely debate this view.
1. There has always been a belief that if weapons are so horribly destructive, and if war is demonstrated to be utterly mutually destructive/insane, then wars will stop occurring. EG, Nobel believed dynamite would end wars; WWI would be 'the war to end all wars'; 'Mutual Assured Destruction' will assure non-use of nuclear weapons; etc. This is a fallacy; large elements of the military & the public will always foolishly choose war when overcome by incitement, rage, and blind nationalism/patriotism. Consider how close India/Pakistan came to nuclear war just las week; a military coup on either side might have triggered it, with the wild support of masses of people on both sides.
2. Although I fingered Putin as one of today's bad guys, the US has started more unjust wars/interventions than any other nation since the 1950s: Iran; Vietnam; Laos; Cambodia; Grenada; Cuba; Chile, El Salvador; Guatemala; Panama; & Iraq as examples.
3. The US/NATO purposefully 'poked the 'Russian Bear' by belittling them for losing the Cold War, by expanding NATO right up to the Russian border, and by deploying SDI capabilities into ex-Warsaw Pact countries just west of Russia. Putin warned of serious consequences, that Russia would not silently 'take it'... and now we're on the verge of (if not into) a new Cold War and a nuclear arms race, with a paranoid Russian leader and citizenry.
4. The Defence/Offence industry in the US is now vaster than even Eisenhower feared or ever imagined. To sustain itself, the military-industrial complex needs powerful, scary enemies and constant threats. How can the US ever get off the war-machine treadmill it now finds itself on?
5. Wars start through blunders; through deep misjudgements about 'the other side'; when neither side will blink; sheer stupidities brought on by misguided nationalism/patriotism; utter paranoia; crazy mistakes (eg. mistaking a rising moon as a swarm of missiles); or because of the threat of intolerable loss of face.
6. There is no way to ensure that a limited engagement between major powers will not quickly switch to total war... as soon as the "Use 'em or lose 'em" thinking kicks in.
7. General Robert Brown is an intelligent, and, I'm sure, a decent person who, no doubt, prefers peace to war, and who, again no doubt, believes that peace comes through military strength. But history is littered with top generals and field marshals who were wrong in their strategies and beliefs.
8. Destin, you said that cyberwarfare can greatly weaken a country by creating deep divisions in its society, and hatreds between groups. You are right... but the greatest damage to your country, to NATO, and to the West in general, is, sadly, being caused by your Commander in Chief.

Destin, before giving my opinion on all this, I'd like to explain where it's coming from. I'm a 41 years old french computer science engineer; I have been programming almost since childhood, beginning with BASIC on a TI99/4A computer in the mid 80s, I was writing assembly code in my teens, so you can understand it's a real passion for me. When I managed to enter one of France's best engineer school, I already knew what my major would be. Yet, I had never thought about ethics in my field. I worked on AI research projects in the late 90s and early 2000s, but it was so clumsy at the time that it never occurred to me it could be a problem - I still don't think AI is a problem on its own, it's the humans designing and using it who are the problem, as a specialist in the field wrote, AI is opinions embedded in mathematics, very powerful mathematics, but the keyword is "opinions".
One day, I was 30 at the time, I saw a science philosophy class from a reknown french physicist and philosopher, Etienne Klein, and he said two things that started me on the path I'm still on today: first, engineer is the one intellectual profession that seem to be absent from the public debate (at least in France, maybe it's different in the US); second, engineers have the skills to design the most simple systems, but not simpler, in order to elegantly solve complex problems, and in this regard, they have a social role to fulfill, and must think deeply about the ethical problems the systems they are building may pose.
Starting from these premises, I came to totally rethink the systems I build, becoming a kind of computer freedom activist in my daily engineer pratice, building systems to empower users and not take freedom away from them, fighting surveillance, centralization, and opinionated AIs seen by most ignorant people in the field as demigods.
As informative most of your videos are, I have always been bothered by the weapon related ones. I told myself it probably came from cultural differences, weapons are very restricted in France, and obviously it's quite different in the US.
I'm not saying that what you do is objectively unethical, there's not such thing as objective ethics. I think I understand why you do this kind of job, and the ethics behind it. But my biggest concerns in today's world being peak oil, climate change, surveillance capitalism, internet centralization at the hands of transnationals and the promethean craziness of transhumanism, seeing people as smart and capable as you and your comrades wasting huge resources, time, money, to analyze how a missile destroys a ship saddens me. Do you really, deeply think this is the best use you could ever have done of your abilities? Don't you think there are more important problems to solve than make the US an invicible, almost godly if you listen to the general, war machine? I'm not a native english speaker, I hope my message is clear enough to help you understand I really don't intend to attack you personnally, I genuinely want to understand how you deal with these questions.

Fantastic video!  The cyber threat is real and we need to invest heavily to ensure we have the best in the world on this front, offensively and defensively.  We've all seen real life examples of the damage that can be done to society just through coordinated malicious social media campaigns.  Now think about all of the essential services that can be disrupted by cyber means, and the damage to society if these services were disrupted for extended periods of time.  The internet itself which would take with it anything that relies on internet connectivity (such as banking and communications), electrical power distribution, banking, fuel distribution, shipping services including essentials like groceries, water processing plants, nuclear power plants, air traffic control, hospitals, GPS (think of all the back end services that depend on GPS for time/synchronization alone, not to mention positioning), cell phone communications, etc..  Many of these these things have already happened proving the vulnerabilities; hospitals crippled by wannacry attacks, the Mirai botnet attack in 2016 that disrupted American DNS and took the entire country of Liberia offline temporarily, air traffic control failure in 2014 due to equipment failure (fire) that took weeks to recover from, the panic caused a few years ago when an error caused a few GPS satellites to broadcast signals just a few microseconds off, the list goes on..  Imagine several of these happening at the same time, on a larger scale and in a way that takes months or years to fix.  If we ignore these threats, we become a real house of cards.

I wanted to facepalm about halfway through this video, and the conclusion actually made me smack my head against a desk. Destin, the problem isn't civility in the political space. It kind of fundamentally misses the point, and General Brown clearly knew that when you bought his propaganda, hook, line and sinker. If I had to pick the clear issue in modern military and political thinking, it's that they're too narrowly focused on what a weapon looks and acts like, and what a national security threat looks and acts like. General Brown even alludes to this in some of his comments, but I can only assume he deliberately avoids discussing it... or at least allowing it in the video.

The problem with your conclusion is that it assumes that the the current status quo isn't causing direct and tangible harm to the world populace, which I would contend is causing the lack of "voluntary unity." You can see it in America, with how the marriage of corporations and politicians has left our infrastructure to rot. Elevated Lead levels throughout the heartland, public schools being defunded to the point where teachers have to work at Walmart to keep a roof over their heads, and automation steadily eating away at jobs that don't require skilled tradespeople and/or college degrees- these things are eating away at the Human resources that an operationally coordinated military desperately needs to function properly, and regional government's lack of response to these challenges does little to convince those who do manage to get out of the trap that the US is a country worthy of serving. You can see it in the Middle East, where the Syrian conflict began over a desired natural gas pipeline, and then grew because of a famine and a lack of clean drinking water caused (at least in part) by Climate Change. Saudia Arabia's disastrous campaign in Yemen, Israel's hypernationalism, Russia's cyberwarfare, and China's desperate attempts to take direct control of the South China Sea are just examples of how behind the US is in terms of what conflicts are going to look like in the future.

Threats are going to come in the form of complex, networked problems and feedback loops that need to be surgically pulled apart to defeat the root causes in detail while simultaneously undercutting any opponents' ability to fight back. Basically, we need to be a complex, networked problem that is just attacking from too many angles for anyone else to deal with. While fighting a war backed with propaganda is nothing new, the number of fronts and the immediacy of response are. The key to this is increasing global stability by shrinking the scale of violent threats, denying bad actors access to the human resources needed to fight, and empowering local people to govern themselves in a manner that is responsive to their needs. To this end, everything that can be used as a weapon should be used- especially nontraditional methods. If a radical terrorist organization is gaining followers, fight them by simultaneously ending hunger/unemployment in the region, building public schools and infrastructure, getting local people trained as teachers, medical personnel, LEOs, and tradespeople, while also performing surgical strikes against known strongholds, tracking and arresting leaders to give fair public trials to, rooting out corruption, and using diplomatic avenues to deny access to outside funding. This all needs to be coordinated for maximum efficiency of resource denial. The US is easily capable of that level of multifaceted warfare over rather large regions, look at how we rebuilt Japan and Europe while fighting in Korea, for instance, but it would mean cleaning up our house a bit... by performing that process on ourselves first, as an educational process for these systems.

We need to learn from the FUBAR results of our interventions in Libya, Afghanistan, Iraq, and especially Syria, and rethink how we project force... and why. Ends don't justify the means, the means build the ends.

So there's the "stop a douchebag" guys in Russia who go around putting big stickers on the windshields of bad or rude drivers who don't follow the rules. I admit, I've watched them. They're entertaining and it feels like the people doing it are taking up a righteous position - and I saw many comments about how Putin had expressed his approval. But now I wonder... were these somehow part of an attempt to prop up an idea in people's minds that Russia is "doing it right"? Was it not just a post-hoc approval from Putin, but rather a deliberately engineered and promoted cyber strategy that his government created?

What we're talking about here is, basically, marketing. It's the same thing companies do on reddit, and for a while it wasn't obvious that it was happening. Am I to believe that some regular private citizen noticed some particular clever movie detail in, say, an Avengers movie - and just so happened to post it to reddit - and got 20 thousand upvotes - a few weeks before the release of the next Avengers movie? Was that really just a natural occurrence which went viral organically? Or was that created and posted by marketers, with upvotes paid for by marketers? How could you ever be sure? Even if Reddit puts out a statement saying that they try to detect and remove hidden marketing - should we believe them? Reddit wants to make money, after all.

There's a lot to think about sure, but I really only have two thoughts which may be of value to others.


First, I know that former members of the armed services struggle sometimes to find jobs. From what I understand (Several members of my family in the military, several friends who fought in war. No service myself) is that one of the problems is that there are not a lot of transferrable skills, especially for combat units. But what the General was saying about empowering soldiers seems to counteract that a bit. Outcome focused leadership, and encouraging initiative in subordinates, seems like a great trait in a manager. Maybe fast tracking veterans into management might be a real possibility. Or post-service cross-training in problem solving fields, like a lot of manufacturing jobs require. Here's a need, figure out how to meet that need. I don't know, it's just the first thing that came to mind. I probably didn't state that as well as I would have hoped. Maybe it's worth exploring more, maybe it ain't.


The second is what Destin was saying about the art of disagreeing well. My aunt and I have very different political opinions. We have never argued, never gotten angry at each other. And we talk about politics a fair amount. We also hug each other, and watch movies together, and exchange christmas gifts. We love each other. And we have never changed the other person's mind. I remember a day when we were driving. We were in the car for several hours. And talked politics the entire ride. Well, that's not entirely true. We also talked architecture. You see, we were in an older part of town, with all the houses unique. And whenever we saw one we liked, we would stop the politics and talk about the house. Then we'd continue. We had more in common with each other than differences due to our political disparity. And we both know how to not become emotionally invested in the outcome of a discussion. We were simply sharing points of view. I understand my aunt a whole lot better, and I think she understands me better too. I don't agree with her any more than before, but maybe that's not really the point. Maybe the art of disagreeing well isn't about argumentation and changing minds, but sharing viewpoints, about understanding each other.


And that's my two cents spent.

One day, a messenger comes to the Mandarin, or king, to inform him that the neighboring town has changed the shape of their walls to a pig – such that it would be interpreted by travelers as being about to eat the orange-shaped town. The messenger and the king discuss frantically how this will bring them ill luck – travelers would stay in and trade with the other town, and nature will favor the pig over the orange. Advised by his daughter, who stands behind a silken screen to hide herself, the king decides to have the town walls rebuilt to resemble a club, with which to beat the pig away. All is well in the town for a time, but soon the messenger brings news that Kwan-Si's walls have been reshaped as a bonfire to burn their club. The Mandarin of the first town has the walls changed to a shining lake; Kwan-Si's are changed to Mouth to drink the lake; the Mandarin's changed to a needle to sew the mouth; Kwan-Si's to a sword to break the needle. This goes on for quite some time, driving the cities' inhabitants away from their work at farms or in shops to fruitlessly rebuild the walls and wait for the other's response. Disease and famine are rampant. At last, the voice behind the silk screen, advising the Mandarin, says weakly "In the Name of the gods, send for Kwan-Si!"

The two Mandarins, both starved and ailing, agree to stop their feud of superstition. The first Mandarin's daughter shows the men several kites, lying abandoned on the ground. 'What are kites,' she asks, 'without the wind to sustain them and make them beautiful?' Nothing, they agree. 'And what is the sky, without kites upon its face to make it beautiful?' Again, it is Nothing. Thus, she directs that Kwan-Si shall make itself to resemble the Silver Wind, and her town shall be made to resemble a Golden Kite, such that the two should sustain each other and they could live in peace.

Some people like to use the terms "bubble" and "echo chamber" to describe, in part, how we've ended up divided.  To me, these descriptions don't quite fit with our modern age.  Bubbles are small, bubbles are your small group of real life friends and family, bubbles are something we had before the internet really took off.  I like to think of what we have today as "biospheres" composed of millions and millions of people all consuming similar content.  For instance, if you're subscribed to this channel, do you also happen to be subscribed to other channels such as Veritasium, Vsauce, Periodic Videos, Mark Rober, Applied Science, Practical Engineering, Cody's Lab, or anything by the Hank & John Green brothers?  How about some of the facebook or news sources you follow?  I think we have a huge overlap of similarly minded individuals and a lot of us may share a high percentage overlap in what content we're consuming, even if it's not identical from person to person.  I think this creates a situation where we can travel all across the net and think we're meeting different people with vastly different viewpoints, but actually they're just more people in our biosphere.  I think for the most part that we never do leave our biospheres completely, and any message we try to convey to those outside our biosphere never actually gets there, it just echoes off the walls and gets "liked."  If you browse around the big news sites, you find that the comment sections (if they allow comments anymore) are just people hurling garbage at one another, and that's not productive.  To an extent, I find stepping away from the internet drama hot spots and interacting with people in real life to be far more productive.  Funny thing about the real world is that people with different opinions can be friends and work together and laugh instead of screaming at each other on the internet.  It's all very strange.  I think at the end of the day it's important to be careful with the content your consuming, and ask yourself if it's designed to elicit a specific response in you that follows a particular narrative you're already biased towards.

The most obvious, immediate problem with that claim is--unity around what? Who gets to decide the center? By the very nature of that issue, you create a central position which can be fought for, and thus creates the division you initially set out to avoid.
I think what perhaps you mean, but haven't exactly said, is that we need to develop an interdependence. Divisions form where communities specify in and out groups, but in an interdependent society, communities have to at least somewhat extend to the groups which support each other. Part of that means giving up American individualism and accepting more shared burden for the society rather than the self or even the household. Part of that means making decisions on what the true wealth of a society is. The point is, divisions don't disappear when people start getting along--people have to get along when you break the divisions down.

It's also really cool to see someone as high up as General Brown recognise the importance of the human element in warfare, as well as the cyber component. Disinformation campaigns, propaganda, and similar are simultaneously magnified and made easier to pull off by the internet. I think it's foolish to not consider the internet a threat for that reason. I also think, and this isn't meant to demean the president (I don't think he has the perspective to see this, any more than your parents/grandparents might), his reckless use of Twitter is really damaging to the U.S.'s standing in world politics, it creates infighting, and because it's a new medium, world leaders don't know whether or not they should take threats and what-not seriously. Also, I believe that Russia runs one of the world's most sophisticated cyber-forces, not because of the technology they employ, but because of the techniques. Unlike our president, Putin knows the power of information, of appearances, and of using the People to win the battle before it's fought. For this reason, I think that Russia is as powerful and as much of a threat as before the Soviet Union's collapse.

Silos are such a challenge to deal with. On one side, they are advantageous because they simplify things (sort of like modular design) and also empower each silo to work independently; but, on the other hand silos can cause big challenges (like when the goals of each silo compete). This is also a big challenge in Engineering. I recall in a company I used to work at we were understaffed and Top Management had us working on five projects that were all "#1" priority. I (one silo) was leading one of those projects but the project was not getting the Purchasing (another silo) resources I needed. What I found out was Purchasing (limited resources) had (in essence) relegated my project to #5 (or you might say, #1.5). This was happening all over the company; so, every project was lacking resources and no project was actually #1. One side is enthusiastic about tolerating the opposition, respecting other's opinions, and so on, but there is one side of the debate that is NOT tolerant of other opinions, and has in fact determined that victory by any means necessary is an acceptable political stance. They don't care about "Disagreeing Well," they want to WIN. When you can't even agree on something basic, like the fact that murder is wrong, what common ground is there to find? You can not stand with a neighbor against a foreign enemy when they both want you dead or on your knees. "United We Stand, Divided We Fall" has long been an American motto, unfortunately there are a whole lot of "Americans" who aren't very "American" anymore. When so few people understand what being "American" even means, it honestly makes me worry about the future, and not just of our nation, but of our species as a whole.

Globalism may well be inevitable at this point, and General Brown may be right about that, but the thing that worries me about that is that it will be a form of globalism that has no place for a Constitution that guarantees our Inalienable Rights and Liberties. The right to own property, to be secure in our possessions, against harm, the ability to pursue Life, Liberty, and Happiness as we see fit, so long as we do not do so at someone else's expense. These are things that I worry that we will lose under the current trend towards globalism, and that desperately needs to change.

Unfortunately, this means that we have a whole lot of Domestic Enemies that need defeating before we can once more stand united against foreign enemies. I hope that it can be done peaceably, but I fear that the "Progressive Left" will continue to use violence and make a peaceful solution impossible.

Re: political grace.
1 piece of advice: stop saying/thinking there is such a thing as neutral ground (I’ll say why in a moment)
Solution: Substitute the word “position” for “neutral”

When we say or imagine this fictitious thing called “neutral ground” the neutral ground becomes the common denominator everyone should defend. But everyone defines that neutral ground differently. And the danger is that once you believe that where you are standing is the neutral ground it is easy to rationalize destroying those who stand outside of it.

The solution to this problem is to say/think that we all hold different positions. If that’s what you say/think, then it is much more difficult to rationalize the destruction of those who hold a different position. If position is how you think and talk, the objective then becomes one of doing what you can to make your position more appealing. It’s not only less dangerous than neutral ground by it is also more effective.

Very hard to counteract that human domain when the core of the system+social media is at conflict with itself (ex. political parties spreading mis-information through twitter or fb about the opposition). How can you combat that? I think Destin is doing a good thing because the best way to combat misinformation is with education, facts, and a lack of bias. I don't think enough of us (myself included) are doing enough to educate others about the pitfalls of unchecked social media. If you talk about regulation however, it's hard not to also step on the first amendment or cross over into propaganda. Tough issues to tackle with no solid answers! I hope companies involved in perpetuating social problems through media learn that in the long term, they're making things worse for everyone just to turn a profit, and hopefully can learn to self-regulate in a manner that benefits everyone.

A lot of these companies now use online analytics data and it is insane at how manipulative companies can be with that data. It doesn't get enough coverage unfortunately. Lets just say if you thought minority report is creepy with their ad targetting, it's not far off. There's also ways retailers can track you without consenting to giving PII data. Everywhere your phone gets tagged and put into a database either with wi-fi or with bluetooth (your phone broadcasts your hardware addresses because that is how it works even if you are not actively connecting to a network), it's game for a lot of other companies using the same tools. It starts forming a fingerprint of your habbits, where you have been, etc. If at some point you have consented to free wi-fi and given out your email, then you can be tied to all your other data without having given consent the other 99% of the time. Now think about how any business for example can subscribe to Purple (business analytics company) or any other analytics company and pull much of that data. It's not hard to start seeing where a bad actor can easily subscribe to all this data and ones that are tech savvy enough can run that data through cheap services like AWS and use their machine learning tools to further enhance the results of the data they are looking for. These lists people get from hacked databases like experion that may match your real name to your email address can then be used to search for hits of your hardware address and coupled with all the public wifi points that use analytics like Meraki to determine where specific people are. I understand how that can sound like some tin-foil hat stuff, but I've been in IT a long time and this stuff is real. You can easily google "business analytics" and see what kind of tools and data are out there and are cheap and easily available.

The point of my long-winded rant is I hope people are aware to make better decisions about how their data is gathered passively and can be abused and that these are also the kinds of things the military is looking at now on the cyber warfare front as a vector of attack and is looking at ways to prevent abuse of our data that can potentially do us harm.

This reminds me of an AI concept. Autonomous Actors. The idea where you have an AI team that must cooperate toward a goal but must also be capable of acting individually toward that end with or without explicit orders to one another. It relies on AI being able to recognize implicit orders, essentially cooperation by best guess of what your team mates are doing when direct communication isn't available. Never seen a particularly good example of it but that's probably just because my AI study was focused more on video games where there's often cheaty tricks utilized which just aren't possible in an actual scenarios where autonomy is needed.

I do like the idea of allowing soldiers to figure out how to achieve a given goal on their own. Opens up utilizing your force towards their unique talents without having to know what those unique talents are. The problem with rigid orders that I've always seen is that it often forces people into scenarios they just aren't the best choice for and creates a massive hole should the plan be revealed to the opponent.

Justin/General this is a very interesting insight.

When we started to embrace capability managment the creation of an effect could be acheived from any domain (Land/Air/Sea).

The intention of adopting 'Capability Managment' was to trade off of the procurement and development of equipments across domains. As things progressed and due to the complexity of those trade off's thinking moved back into the traditional stove pipe thinking within each of those domains. It is intresting that the US have added the Cyber and Space domains.

It would be very interesting to see whether the US can break free from the traditional stove pipe thinking to take a more holistic approach to 'Capability Managment'.

Since the introduction of SMART procurement and 'Capability Managment' staff working in each of the traditional demains appear to have re-defined 'Capability' to mean something physical like a ship, aircraft, submarines, tank, etc., thus simplifing this complex issue.

Perhaps you could do a video to explain 'Effect/Capability Managment' thinking and how trade off's can be acheived.

I'm surprised he didn't get into it more, but beyond empowering individuals within the military to make decisions and believe in what they're a part of, I think the even more important battle in the human domain is winning over the people we're at conflict with. In Iraq and Afghanistan the fight to convince the common people that we represent their best interests more than the local terrorist organizations is arguably much more important than any of the traditional military battles going on over there. (And I hope they are convinced because we actually have their best interests in mind and not because we're deceiving them.) You saw the same thing in Vietnam. We could win the traditional military battles but we lost the people, and that's why we lost the war. (We were probably on the wrong side to begin with, but that's a whole different argument.)

More broadly we can use that strategy not only to win conflicts but to prevent them. A country's government is going to have a hard time starting a war with us if all the common people in the country have a positive opinion on us. It's just not going to go over well, especially in a democratic country, but even in an authoritarian country a general positive view of us could create internal conflict among military leaders who might not believe they should be fighting against us.

I think a better way to put disagreeing well would be to disagree or criticize constructively. If everyone agrees to disagree, then we just all sit around remaining politely divided. The only way to mend that division is to discuss these issues with people that we believe to disagree with us completely. The chance that you disagree with someone on everything that someone values or believes is practically nonexistent, a lot of the time people who consider themselves to be total opposites actually share a lot of core values, but they disagree with the conclusion that the other person reached. Also, if you can't criticize constructively, then don't criticize at all. The problem with all of this is that these are not ways that we are designed to be able to look at the world. I am writing a legal paper right now on the dangers of applying AI and machine learning algorithms in social media and the problems that come up are intense. Because what happens is that the people designing the AI or pointing the machine learning at a certain goal are not cognizant of the tricks that can be used to manipulate the human mind. The basic flaws in human logic can be and are exploited to, for instance, increase average watch times on YouTube. That causes damage that we are not used to attributing to a source.


Such as the recent rise of the anti-vax movement. It has been pushed by certain sites because once a person is down that rabbit-hole they are more likely to stay stuck there. Once they're stuck they, incidentally, see many more ads. It was never the goal of the site to make that person believe in anti-vax, but it was one of the unintended consequences. The problem then is how and who do you hold accountable for the actions of a black boxed algorithm? I don't know yet and I don't think anybody else does either.

A very important component of this space was narrative and how, in today’s world, cyberspace and media allow narrative to be manipulated in order to maneuver to a position of advantage within the cognitive battlespace. Anyway. I think the scary reality of the people/cyber issue is that we've already lost. These bad actors aren't creating divisions which didn't exist, they're just amplifying ones they find and pushing them away from resolution towards chaos. But these divisions DO exist. We don't all agree on everything and there are real political struggles to be had over important issues which affect real people. But wow wouldn't it be convenient for the people in power if we stopped pushing for change because we've been made to believe that there is no real dissent, only paid trolls and foreign agents trying to manipulate us. But at the same time, there are some trolls trying to manipulate us and if you're not always guarded, you risk frustrating yourself or getting mislead by engaging with them. So what is the proper response? If you take people at face value you'll end up getting taken advantage of by trolls. If you become hypercritical to a point where you think that anyone who disagrees with you is probably a troll, then you're just disengaging from the political process and retreating into an echo chamber that favors the status quo over addressing potential problems. The naive answer is that everyone should become their own personal journalist/fact checker/scientist and closely review every piece of information, article, source, etc which you encounter online. But that just isn't realistic. The world's just too complicated to verify all information yourself. At some point you need to be able to trust others to provide you with their accounts of the world. But what is that trust based on? Why should I trust the military, the government, this news organization or that, scientists, someone on the internet, etc? Sometimes there's a satisfying enough answer: Science is trust-able because of it's methodology and peer-review process; but a lot of the time there isn't a good answer.

“War. War never changes.

In the year 1945, my great-great grandfather, serving in the army, wondered when he'd get to go home to his wife and the son he'd never seen. He got his wish when the US ended World War II by dropping atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

The World awaited Armageddon; instead, something miraculous happened. We began to use atomic energy not as a weapon, but as a nearly limitless source of power.

People enjoyed luxuries once thought the realm of science fiction. Domestic robots, fusion-powered cars, portable computers. But then, in the 21st century, people awoke from the American dream.
Years of consumption lead to shortages of every major resource. The entire world unraveled. Peace became a distant memory. It is now the year 2077.
